meanings.definition: a sex chromosome (= a structure containing chemical patterns) that usually exists as a pair in the cells of women and many female animals and with a Y-chromosome in the cells of men and many male animals:
examples: The genes that cause red-green colour blindness are located on the X chromosome.

meanings.definition: the 24th letter of the English alphabet
in Roman numerals (= the letters used by the ancient Romans to write numbers), the number 10:
examples: 10 is X in Roman numerals.
What does an X stand for in Roman numerals?
25 is written XXV in Roman numerals.

meanings.definition: used when voting to mark the name of the person that you are choosing:
examples: Put an X beside the name of the candidate you want to vote for.

meanings.definition: used especially in the past to refer to a film or show that is not suitable for people under 18 years old because it contains violence or sex:
examples: No one under the age of 18 is allowed at an X-rated film.
At the time it was released, the film was given an X rating.

meanings.definition: used to represent a number, or the name of person or thing that is not known or stated:
examples: If 2x = 8, then x = 4.
Witness x stated that she had seen Cooper on repeated occasions.

meanings.definition: used at the end of an informal piece of writing to represent a kiss:
examples: Write soon, all my love, Katy xxx

meanings.definition: written on an answer to a question to show that the answer is not correct
to remove something from a list:
examples: I x'ed out all the names of the people I wouldn't be sending cards to.

meanings.definition: used to represent a number, or the name of person or thing, that is not known or stated:
examples: If 2x = 8, then x = 4.

meanings.definition: the 24th letter of the English alphabet
the Roman numeral for the number 10
a brand name for a sharp knife with a short blade that can be replaced
the line of figures or coordinates that are arranged from left to right on a graph or map:
examples: In the graph the x-axis is price and the y-axis is quantity.
The general rule is that the variable you control is plotted on the x-axis and the variable that changes as a result is plotted on the y-axis.

meanings.definition: a horizontal line that forms one side of a coordinate plane (= region formed by two number lines)
the horizontal line of figures along the bottom of a graph, often representing time:
examples: The x-axis represents expenditure and the y-axis profit.

meanings.definition: a situation in which a company or a particular machine produces the largest possible number of goods with the time, materials, or labour that it has available:
examples: The report showed that banks were still operating at 60% below the x-efficiency level.

meanings.definition: a situation in which a company or a particular machine fails to produce the largest possible number of goods with the time, materials, or labour that it has available:
examples: The company's x-inefficiency and high prices are mainly the result of a lack of competition in the market.

meanings.definition: a rare genetic condition in which low levels of immunoglobulins (= proteins that destroy harmful bacteria) affect the body's ability to fight infection
a rare genetic condition in which low levels of immunoglobulins (= proteins that destroy harmful bacteria) affect the body's ability to fight infection
(of movies, electronic images, books, magazines, etc.) containing very rude language or pictures or information about sex that is generally considered offensive
(of movies, electronic images, books, magazines, etc.) containing very rude language or pictures or information about sex that is generally considered offensive
used especially in sports reports to refer to a dangerous tackle made by a football player:
examples: The Chelsea boss is furious with the Stoke defender for his X-rated challenge on Oscar.

meanings.definition: a type of radiation that can go through many solid substances, allowing hidden objects such as bones and organs in the body to be photographed:
examples: A CT scan uses X-rays to take a picture of everything under the skin.

meanings.definition: a photograph of a part of the body made using X-rays:
examples: The X-ray showed a slight irregularity in one lung.
The tumour showed up on the X-ray.

meanings.definition: an examination of a part of the body by taking and studying an X-ray photograph:
examples: She had an X-ray to see if any of her ribs were broken.
You may need to go for an X-ray on that arm.

meanings.definition: to take a photograph of the inside of someone or something using X-rays:
examples: His hip had to be X-rayed.
All hand luggage is X-rayed at the airport.

meanings.definition: a type of radiation (= energy in movement) that can go through many solid substances, allowing hidden objects such as bones in the body to be photographed
An X-ray is also a photograph of a part of the body made by using X-rays:
examples: Fortunately the X-rays showed no broken bones.

meanings.definition:
abbreviation for
        
         ex-all
a very impressive and beautiful place, or a place that is perfect:
examples: The publishing mogul hosted lavish fetes at his own Xanadu, a vast estate.
Oxford was my Xanadu, my vision of literary delight.
Herds of deer, golden eagles overhead, and not another soul in sight. This was Xanadu.

meanings.definition: a brand name for a drug used to treat anxiety:
examples: She tried to obtain the anti-anxiety drug Xanax from a pharmacy in Tallahassee, the police said.
It turns out she was taking Xanax for depression.

meanings.definition: a chemical substance that is used in industrial processes, for example the production of food, to make liquids thicker and firmer:
examples: Xanthan gum is used to thicken dairy products and salad dressings.
Xanthan gum has also been added to concrete poured underwater, in order to increase its viscosity.

meanings.definition:
abbreviation for
        
         eXtensible Business Reporting Language

abbreviation for
        
         ex-capitalization

abbreviation for
        
         ex-dividend
a chemical element that is a gas with no colour or smell. Xenon does not react with other elements and is used in some types of light bulb.
a person who strongly dislikes or fears foreigners, their customs, their religions, etc.
extreme dislike or fear of foreigners, their customs, their religions, etc.
showing an extreme dislike or fear of people from foreign countries:
examples: There have been outbursts of xenophobic violence.
The attacks have been described by police as racist and xenophobic.

meanings.definition: in a way that shows or expresses an extreme dislike or fear of people from foreign countries:
examples: Police believe that the attack on this immigrant neighbourhood was xenophobically motivated.
We have a diverse community, and there will be no tolerance for those who act xenophobically towards their fellow students.

meanings.definition: the process of transplanting an organ or another part of the body from one species (= set of animals with similar characteristics) to a different species:
examples: In the absence of sufficient human donors, research into xenotransplantation is seen as increasingly important.

meanings.definition: (of a virus, etc.) able to reproduce (= produce copies of itself) only in an organism that is from a different species than the host organism (= the one that it lives on):
examples: Xenotropic viruses developed from cows and other animals are often used in the production of vaccines.
Scientists found no link between the condition and xenotropic murine leukemia virus.

meanings.definition: to design a garden, park, etc. in such a way that it needs as little water as possible:
examples: You don't need to xeriscape to save water in your garden.
By xeriscaping the entire east slope of its factory grounds, the company significantly reduced its need for irrigation water.

meanings.definition: a method of designing a garden, park, etc. so that it needs as little water as possible, or a garden, park, etc. that is designed in this way:
examples: Landscaping has had to change, with people having to look at xeriscape and alternative technologies.
One advantage of Xeriscape or drought-tolerant landscaping is that it can be watered using drip irrigation systems, thus saving water.
The home has xeriscape landscaping and a roof constructed of energy efficient materials.

meanings.definition: the practice of designing a garden, park, etc. in such a way that it needs as little water as possible:
examples: The plants used for xeriscaping will be more likely to survive periods of drought or water restrictions that are placed on your community.
He said that everyone was interested in xeriscaping, or choosing plants that require no additional watering.

meanings.definition: an area of land that has been designed to use as little water as possible:
examples: Many local people aren't happy with desert-like landscapes or xeriscaping, because it just doesn't look pretty.
The school district is replacing much of the grass at schools with xeriscaping.

meanings.definition:
→ 
        
         electrophotography  :
examples: Chester Carlson developed xerography, a tool that would be crucial to the Information Age.
The Xerox Corporation, then called the Haloid Company, bought rights to the xerography process.

meanings.definition: a brand name for a copy of a document or other piece of paper with writing or printing on it, made by a machine that uses a photographic process, or the machine or process itself:
examples: a Xerox of the letter
a Xerox machine

meanings.definition: to make a copy of a document using a Xerox or other copying machine
a copy of a document or other piece of paper with writing or printing on it made by a machine that uses a process similar to that for making photographs:
examples: I can give you a Xerox of the letter if you like.

meanings.definition: a brand name for a copy of a written or printed document, made by a machine using a photographic process:
examples: Could you send me a Xerox of the contract?

meanings.definition: a brand name for a type of machine that uses a photographic process to make copies of written or printed documents:
examples: a Xerox machine

meanings.definition: to make a copy of a document by using a Xerox machine:
examples: I need to xerox the report before the meeting.

meanings.definition:
past simple and past participle of 
        
         Xerox
to make a copy of a document using a Xerox or other copying machine

present participle of 
        
         Xerox
to make a copy of a document using a Xerox or other copying machine
abbreviation for extensible hypertext markup language: a way of marking text to be shown on computer systems and the internet
the 14th letter of the Greek alphabet
the smallest and lowest part of the sternum (= the long, flat, vertical bone in the centre of the chest), formed of cartilage (= strong tissue):
examples: The chest circumference was obtained at the level of the xiphisternum.
It is often midway between xiphisternum and umbilicus.

meanings.definition: shaped like a sword (= a weapon used in the past with a long, sharp metal blade)
relating to the xiphoid process (= a lower part of the long, flat bone in the centre of the chest)
the smallest and lowest part of the sternum (= the long, flat, vertical bone in the centre of the chest), formed of cartilage (= strong tissue):
examples: The xiphoid process is largely cartilaginous in structure, and completely ossifies late in life.
In children, the heel of one hand is positioned over a compression point two fingers' breadth above the xiphoid process.

meanings.definition: abbreviation for extra large: used to describe or refer to someone or something, usually an item of clothing, that is very large:
examples: Sizes available: S, M, L, XL, and XXL.
I like the sweatshirt but don't they make an XL?
He's an XL but I'm an XS, so his shirts are huge on me.
Do you have the same jacket in XL?
The shirts come in L and XL.

meanings.definition: abbreviation for extra large; used esp. on clothing to show its size

abbreviation for
        
         Christmas  :
examples: Merry Xmas to all our customers.

meanings.definition: abbreviation for Christmas
abbreviation for extensible mark up language: a way of marking text to be shown in computer systems
abbreviation for Extensible Markup Language: a computer language used for creating and organizing electronic text according to a particular set of rules that allow it to be shared, especially online
a kind of dog of small to medium size that comes from Mexico and that has almost no hair apart from on its head and tail:
examples: The Xoloitzcuintli will sometimes have a very thin coat of fur with thicker fur around the head and tail.
The Xoloitzcuintli is sometimes known as Xolo for short.

meanings.definition:
abbreviation for
        
         ex-rights
abbreviation for extra small: used to describe or refer to someone or something, usually an item of clothing, that is very small :
examples: Try an XS tee over a pair of leggings or jeans.
Sizes available: XS, S, M, L, XL, and XXL.
I like the sweatshirt but don't they make an XS?
He's an XL but I'm an XS, so his shirts are huge on me.
Do you have the same jacket in XS?
The shirts come in S and XS.

meanings.definition: the most important facts or ideas or things connected with something, usually used to refer to the systems and plans that help you to be successful in particular sports :
examples: It's not the system, it's not the Xs and Os, it's the guys on the field that win football games.
These are the Xs and Os of dog training.
He studied the playbook for hours and hours during the season trying to understand all the Xs and Os.
X's and O's became a shorthand expression to refer to the details of football techniques, play design, and strategy.

meanings.definition:
written abbreviation for
        
         extension
a unit of money formerly used in Vietnam. It was equal to one hundredth of a dong (= the standard unit of money used in Vietnam):
examples: The dong was subdivided into 10 hào and 100 xu.
The 50 xu coin is silver with pictures of three women on it.

meanings.definition: abbreviation for extra extra large: used to describe or refer to someone or something, usually an item of clothing, that is extremely large :
examples: Sizes available: S, M, L, XL, and XXL.
I like the sweatshirt but don't they make an XXL?
Airlines need to improve the travel experience for XXL passengers.
Do you have the same jacket in XXL?
We have two sizes of flowerpot: the Very Large pot and the XXL pot.

meanings.definition: the type of plant tissue that carries water and minerals from the roots to the leaves and gives support to the stem or trunk
the plant tissue that carries water from the roots to the leaves and gives strength to the stem or trunk
a musical instrument consisting of flat wooden bars of different lengths that are hit with sticks
a musical instrument of flat, wooden bars of different lengths that produce notes when hit with sticks
a person who plays the xylophone (= a musical instrument consisting of flat wooden bars of different lengths that are hit with sticks):
examples: There were superb solo turns by the band's xylophonist and saxophonist.
He is a xylophonist in the Navy Drum and Bugle Corps.
